loans.name: Ton

texts.en: Mrs. Ton Y. was born in 1968 and has been married many years to Mr. Bunheang, age 49. He is a taxi driver and a construction employee. This couple has five kids. Three of the children are no longer in school and work as waiters for wedding parties while the remaining two attend school. Ton Y. is an internal employee for a non-government organization and has been doing this occupation for years. Ton Y. and her family faced difficulties with their electricity line use because their house is far from the electricity system. Due to that, Ton Y. decided to seek a loan to buy a generator to supply electricity for her family’s needs.

loans.use: To buy a generator

loans.name: Rosemarie's Group

texts.en:
Rosemarie S. is from the village of Rang-Ayan. She is 38 years old. Rosemarie is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosemarie's Group.

Rosemarie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rosemarie owns & operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rosemarie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Rosemarie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Chhoam

texts.en: Chhoam S., 45, is married and lives with two school-aged children in Battambong town, Cambodia. S. is engaged in the business of selling porridge and soup at her home. She is able to earn an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family’s expenses. Her husband operates his motorbike as a taxi driver, earning an income of US $4 per day. He always provides his service at the markets in the town. S. and her family members try to work hard every day to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of US $1000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to purchase a new motorbike for her husband because the old motorbike often needs to get repaired. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: Pedirama

texts.en:
Pedirama B. is from the city of Gango ozamiz City. She is 34 years old. Pedirama is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Pedirama owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling snacks like rice cake "puto" and hot halo-halo "benignit" in the community. Pedirama has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Pedirama joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Pedirama has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from GDMPC. Pedirama is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Pedirama from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products that she sells.

To make a living, Annabelle owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products such as sugar, rice, canned goods (beefloaf and sardines), shampoo, soap (bath and laundry) and other daily use products in the local community. Annabelle has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Annabelle joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Annabelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40000 PHP from GDMPC. Annabelle is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Annabelle from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Prak V. was married a long time ago to Mr. Om York and they are blessed with four young children who are not longer in school. The couple is helped financially by all of their children, from their working in different jobs: two are building workers, one is a garment worker and the remaining one raises poultry from home for a profit. Presently Prak V. and her husband have a piece of land where they plant many kinds of crops to earn a living. Recently they lacked some supplies for their farming business. Prak V. has requested a loan of US$700 to use towards growing crops. (Prak V. was busy at her farm work, so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To grow crops.

loans.name: Ian

texts.en:
Ian G. is from the village of Cabungaan Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 31 years old. Ian is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ian owns & operates a business providing motor services to local community members. Ian has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Ian joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to engage in business activities. Ian has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. He is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a transport vehicle to improve the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Ian from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun V., 37, is married and lives with his young child in Battambong town, Cambodia. V. is engaged in the agriculture sector as a rice field farmer and is able to earn an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family’s expenses. He spends time on his plot of farmland every day to take care and grow crops. His wife (pictured here) sells used clothes at the market, earning an income of USD 4 per day. V. and his wife try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for their family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, V. is requesting for a loan of US $1000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. He wants to use the loan to purchase more used clothes and wood to build a suitable stand for this current major business. This is his first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn S. is from the city of Malaubang Ozamiz City. She is 29 years old. Emelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. Emelyn owns & operates a retail store selling used shoes and clothes in the local community. Emelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Emelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan M., 59, is a grocer and the mother of two young school-aged children. She is married to Mr. Ron, 66, a taxi driver. (Chan M. was not available for photographing, so her husband is pictured.) Chan M. hopes to generate more income for her family and is asking for a loan to build a small shop in front of her home where her husband will provide a vehicle repair service.

loans.use: To build a small shop.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en: Sen V., 36, is married and lives with his wife in Battambong town, Cambodia. V. is engaged in the agriculture sector growing orange trees on his own plot of farmland. He is able to earn an income of USD 1.5 per day to help cover the family’s expenses. He spends time on his plot of farmland every day taking care of his crops. His wife sells vegetables and fruit at a market located in the center of the town, earning an income of USD 8 per day. V. and his wife try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for their family. They are seeking to improve their businesses. As a result, V. is requesting for a loan of US $1000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. He wants to use the expected loan to purchase more fruit to sell to his new and existing customers. This is his first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more fruit for sale.

loans.name: Mrs. Chin Chouch Village Bank Group

texts.en: Sixteen people who all live in Knong Prek village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan and they will use the loan for various purpose. Mrs. Chin C. is the 61-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small field to cultivate both rice and vegetables. In vegetable farming, she now faces a problem because she does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy them. Her husband, Mr. Tip Soth, helps her with the farming. Mrs. Chin C. has two children. One of her children is a farmer and the other is a waiter.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Uch

texts.en: Uch L., 42 years old, has been married for a long time and has no children yet. To earn a living, Uch L. and his wife built a pigpen next to their house where they feed many pigs and sell them for income. The couple will sell all their pigs to buyers after their pigs are mature. Recently Uch L. has used all the food he has in stock to feed his pigs and he lacks money to buy more feed. Therefore, Uch L. requests a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL to be used to purchase pig feed and more piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase pig food and piglets

loans.name: Mr. Vann Ny Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank, which consists of 11 members, is located in Knong Prek village in Kandal province. They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mr. Vann N. is the village bank president. He has been selected by the members. He is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to support the family. His wife, Mrs. Chraing Sophy, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate both rice and vegetable. In this farming, she now has a problem because she does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds. So her husband decided to ask for a loan to buy vegetable seeds for his wife. Mr. Vann N. is a father of four children. Three of the children are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds for his wife's farm

loans.name: Din

texts.en: Din M. is 42 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang province, where she has established a small family. She is married with four children, three of whom attend school while the other one is an employee in the pure water company. Din M. is a local teacher for a public school, while her husband has the skills to examine patients in the village (as a medical doctor.) The couple also takes time to cultivate a rice crop as their annual business. Due to the coming dry season and the weather becoming dry everywhere, Din M. is hardly finding enough water for their crop. Din M. is applying for a loan to buy a machine and pump to irrigate her rice crop.

loans.use: To buy a machine and water pump.

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthy Soa Village Bank Group

texts.en: This is a village bank loan with fourteen members, and they all live in Knong Prek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Chanthy S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She and her husband, Mr. Chin Choeurn, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate vegetables. Aside from this they are vegetable sellers in the local market. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so Mrs. Chanthy S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to re-sell. Mrs. Chanthy S. is a mother of two children who are both too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to re-sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

To make a living, Erlinda runs a firewood store in her local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Erlinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Salman Group

texts.en:
This is Salman Group. This group has four members: Nasima, Yasamen, Azatullah and Shukrullah. They all keep busy in different businesses and they have requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani. Nasima, who is the group leader, is married and has five children - two sons and three daughters. She runs a quilt making business and she wants to buy cloth and thread to make more quilts. This is the only business through which she supports her children and husband. Yasamen is a tailor. Since the Taliban regime she has sewed clothes because at that time they had lots of economic problems. Now by the Kiva loan she wants to buy a new sewing machine and wants to start her business anew to support her husband and children. Azatullah has a public bath, and he wants to buy the necessary equipment for his public bath. Shukrullah has a retail shop, and he wants to buy the essential materials which are demanded in the market, to attract more customers. With the income from his shop he supports his family members and his reason for requesting a loan is to expand his business.
They would like to say many thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy quilt making materials.

loans.name: Tsuma

texts.en:
Tsuma Z. is a married man with four children. He operates a drafting and painting business in Mariakani town. He has been in this business for the last five years and the business is doing well.

Tsuma was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, by a member of the same group that he joined. He is now borrowing his first loan. With the money, he intends expand his business, which is in high demand in the area. He also plans to purchase more brushes and paints that he will continue using in his business. 

His dream is to expand the business of drafting by printing logos, T-shirts and other garments.

loans.use: To purchase brushes and paints and to establish another office for his drafting business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet J. is a married woman with five children. She lives in Mariakani in the Coast province, where she is a tailor. Janet has been doing the tailoring business for the last 21 years. She also supplements her income by training four part-time students in tailoring for a fee.

Janet is a member of the Lenga Self Help Group and is the chairperson of the group. The group has a good credit history with KADET, a Kiva partner. This is Janet's third loan and her business has been able to expand through the KADET loans. She will use the current loan to purchase garments from Uganda for making clothes and to also purchase materials to make school uniforms. Her main customers are the people from the community around her business area and also her friends. 

Janet's dream is to expand her training class and enroll more students, that way she will be able to maximize her profits while serving the community more.

loans.use: To purchase garments from Uganda for making clothes and to also purchase materials to make school uniforms

loans.name: Bou

texts.en:
Bou S. was born in 1952 and was married a long time ago, but her husband died of senility. Currently she has two married and three younger children who are no longer in school. One of her daughters is a garment-industry worker. 

To make a living, Bou S. has used her own farmland to farm rice for a profit. Bou S. planted drying rice a month ago and now she lacks a watering system for her crop due to the weather becoming too dry everywhere. Because of this obstacle, Bou S. requested a loan to purchase a pumping machine to irrigate her rice crop.

loans.use: To purchase a pumping machine to irrigate her rice crop

loans.name: Ayiko Faidah Jescah Group

texts.en: F. Jescah, 28 years old, is the group's representative. She lives with her spouse and they are blessed with one child. She has been selling fish for over five years. She is using the loan to purchase more fish to sell for better profits. With the loans, her standard of living is improving and her profits are increasing too. She is a hardworking and promising business lady whose dreams are to educate her children and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Riel

texts.en: Riel R., age 40, is married with five children. Two of the children employed in the garment factory and other three are students and dependent on her income. She currently uses her own land next to her house to grow rice and vegetable crops to earn a living. Riel R. also relies on her husband’s income as a military policeman to support their family. Riel R. has bought housing equipment, which she plans to use to build a new house but the construction is not able to start due to the lack of some essential tool. Therefore, Riel R. decided to seek a loan of $1050 to be used to purchase enough tools to begin building new house.

loans.use: To purchase enough tools to begin building her new house

loans.name: Mrs. Phoeun Chuon Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of 13 people and they all live in Kandal village in Takeo province. Mrs. Phoeun C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a broom seller. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more brooms to re-sell. Her husband, Mr. Paok Reth, helps her to sell brooms to support the family. Mrs. Phoeun C. is a mother of two children who both local school.

loans.use: To buy more brooms to re-sell.

loans.name: Omid-E-Sarak Dowom Group

texts.en:
The Omid-e-Sarak Dowom group is made up of four female members. Soma is the group leader. She is 35, married and has a beauty salon in which she is busy during week days. She is a hard-working woman and all her family members benefit from the income she generates. She has requested a loan to buy new quality cosmetics and some other required materials necessary for the progress of her business.

Another member of this group is Bebe Keshwar who wants to take out a loan for her son’s gas selling shop. With the loan, he would like to purchase more gas balloons. The third member is Fahima who wants to take out a loan for her husband’s retail shop and the last member, Zahera, would like to take out a loan for her brother’s general store which he will use to buy more materials.

They all have requested a group loan of 56000 Afghani.

loans.use: To expand and progress their businesses

loans.name: Mrs. Oem Lon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Ten people who all live in Kandal village in Takeo province make up the village bank loan. Mrs. O. Lon is the village bank president who has been selected by the members who will all use the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who has a small piece of land to cultivate rice.

Her husband, Mr. Sor Borey, is a rice wine maker. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it so Mrs. O. Lon decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice for her husband to make more wine. Mrs. O. Lon is the mother of two children who are both too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy rice for her husband to make wine.

loans.name: So

texts.en:
Mr. So S., 33 years old, has been married for a long time and has four children, who are in school. To earn a living, So S. always leaves home to work at construction locations, while his wife helps build up the family income by making clayish pens and cookers from home. The couple is able to generate their income of $7 each day which they use to serve their family’s daily food needs.

So S. owns land that he inherited form his grandmother on which he hopes to farm rice. As he lacks money, he has applied for capital from Kiva’s partner, HKL, to purchase fertilizer, seeds and other supplies for farming rice.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds and other supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Makara Phan Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 15 people located in Smau Khchei village in Takeo province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Makara P. is the village bank president. She is 21 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. 

Mrs. Makara P. is a laborer who makes a small income to support her family. Since the workplace is far from home, she needs to use more money on transportation. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to bU. a motorbike to go to work. Her husband, Mr. Pich Socheat, is a soldier who makes a small income to support the family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to go to work.

loans.name: Aiivu Bako Mary Group

texts.en: B. Mary is 45 years of age, a single businesswoman blessed with three children. She has carried out a local brewing business since 2006. The loan is helping her to boost her business by inserting more capital into the business. At least she is now getting settled in her home and the loan is encouraging her to think very fast and work very hard to accomplish her dreams. Her future plan is to obtain livestock as assets, such as cows, goats and so forth.

loans.use: To insert more capital to boost her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Yan Prach Village Bank Group

texts.en: This is a village bank loan consisting of seventeen people who live in Smau Khchei village in TaK. province. Mrs. Yan P. is the elected village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a 0.5 hectare field of land where she cultivates rice. She is also a pig breeder. Since her breeding pig business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing another pig for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Nu Non, is a driver who make a small income to support the family. Mrs. Yan P. is the mother of four children who are all enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a pig for breeding.

loans.name: Liza's Group

texts.en:
Liza R. is from the village of Tabbaruk, San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 49 years-old. Liza is the leader of a ten member group loan offered by Kiva partner ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Liza is widowed and has two adult children. Liza owns and operates a general store which sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 500 PHP a day.

In 2008, Liza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Liza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and North-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen K. is a widowed mother caring for two young children. Both of her children are law abiding persons who currently work sewing clothes in the garment factory in Phnom Penh. Currently she has a fish paste business: she buys fresh fish in bulk and then turns it into fish paste to sell or to trade with  rice from farmers. Pen K. says that she lives in an older house that affects her living conditions adversely. Therefore, she would like to borrow $500 to repair her existing house. With any remaining funds she will make more fish paste.

loans.use: Home repair.

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en: Meoun C., 25, is married and lives with three young children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. C. has a business of selling grilled eggs and is able to earn a gross income of USD 50 per day to help cover the family expenses. She always travels to the town of her province to sell her egg products. Her husband sells roast chickens in the town, earning a gross income of USD 58 per day. C. and her husband work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They would like to improve their businesses as well. As a result, C. is requesting a loan of US $500 from Kiva partner CREDIT. She wants to use the loan to purchase an ice crusher. The machine will help her make coconut juice shakes for her customers.  This will be her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To purchase an ice crusher.

loans.name: Prima

texts.en:
Prima G. is from the village of Cabisera 27. She is 38 years-old and married with two school-aged children. Prima owns and operates a business in the agriculture sector raising pigs for sale. Prima has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Prima joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Prima has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Prima is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Prima from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and North-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa U. is from the village of San Roque Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old, married, and has five adult children. To make a living, Elisa owns and operates a business operating a specialized retail store, making and selling tamarind candy, sweet potato candy, peanuts and more in the local community. Elisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $110 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Elisa joined the Kiva field partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Elisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Elisa is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hin

texts.en:
This photo presents Mrs. Hin S., a woman who subsists on a low-income. She lives in Kampong Chhnang province. Hin is a widowed mother who is blessed with one daughter. The daughter has completed secondary school and presently works in the garment industry. Hin farms a rice crop to earn a living.

Recently Hin decided that she could earn more money from investing in a new enterprise. She has asked for a loan to use as capital to order mature rice from other farmers, which she will then sell to raise revenue.

loans.use: To order mature rice to sell.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda D. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old, married, and has three adult children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns and operates a business, buying and selling coconut in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $115 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined the Kiva field partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue that is generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mr. Sim But Village Bank Group

texts.en:
TE. members, who are all living in Chek village in Kandal province, constitute this village bank loan. Mr. Sim B. is the village bank president who was selected by the members, and they will each use the loan for different purposes.

Mr. Sim B. and his wife, Mrs. Lung Bor, are farmers who own a plot of land where they cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he sells chickens. Lately, he has a problem with his field because it has infertile soil. He decided to ask for what will be his 3rd loan to buy fertilizers, and also for buying fuel.

He is the father of six childrE., three of whom are garment factory laborers, while the other three help their parents on the farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and fuel.

loans.name: Ayiko Yesco Stella Group

texts.en:
Y. Stella is the group president; she is 35 years old, married, and has five children, three of whom are going to school.

She operates a local brewing business, started twenty years ago. This loan is helping her to raise capital, as she is trying to stock as much as she can of the local brewing ingredients, such as millet, sorghum, yeast, and so forth, for making the local brew to sell. The loan is encouraging Y. to work very hard with no letup.

She is an active and hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to build and to obtain a cow with the increased revenue.

loans.use: To stock local brew ingredients

loans.name: Ayiko Wadiko Madelena Group

texts.en:
W. Madelena is fifty years old and is representing her group. She is a single woman who is blessed with six children of whom one is going to school.

Madelena has carried out a local brew business for three years so far. Due to her small amount of capital, she is using the loan to purchase local brew ingredients such as millet flour, yeast, sorghum, and so forth, for making local brew to sell.

Medically and health-wise Madelena is improving together with her family and, more so, feeding is no longer a problem. Generally, her business is improving.

Madelena is a promising businesswoman whose future hope is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients for making local brew

loans.name: Zainab Zarmina Group

texts.en:
The Zainab Zarmina group is made up of four members.
Amina is the group leader. She is married and the supporter of the seven members of her family. Amina wants to take a loan for her son. For more than two years he has had a fresh fruit cart, and with this loan he wants to buy more fruit for his cart.
Zarmina is the second member of Zainab Zarmina group. She has a carpet-weaving business, the income from which she uses to support her family. Her purpose in requesting a loan is to expand her business.
The third member of the group is Shokria, who is an embroiderer. With this loan she wants to buy some necessary things for her embroidery business.
The last member of Zainab Zarmina group is Zainab. She is busy with her carpet-weaving business. With this loan she wants to buy more materials for her weaving.
These four members have requested a group loan of 40,000 AFN. They want to thank all lenders from Kiva and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more fruit for her son's fruit cart

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Say K. is skilled at making clay cooking pots by hand. She learned this skill from her grandparents who died many years ago. Each day, she can produce many sets of her item, and she saves up nearly a hundred sets before taking them out to sell. She also provides her finished items to her husband to sell in the community. In the past, Say K. hired a neighbor’s cow cart to pick up her items to sell. Now she hopes to reduce this cost by taking a loan to purchase a cart to connect with her existing cow. She will then use this new cart as transport for her goods.

loans.use: To purchase a cart

loans.name: Mrs. Sengly Tun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank group consists of eleven members who are located in Chek village, Kandal province. They will all use their loans for different purposes.
Mrs. Sengly T. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a laborer in a garment factory while her husband, Mr. Veany Nam, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Currently, her husband’s field has infertile soil. Therefore, Mrs. Sengly T. has decided to ask for a third loan to buy both fertilizers and rice seed. The couple has two children who are too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seed

loans.name: Juaben Ladies Group

texts.en:
Mariama is 38 years old, married, and the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. She has been sewing for five years now, specializing in womenswear and funeral dresses. Her skills and designs are of high class. She makes various kinds of clothing styles to give her customers a new look – for example, children's school uniform, church attire, kaba and slit (a tailored top and long skirt), wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc. She wants to use her loan to buy increased supplies of sewing materials such as linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. Through her dedication and hard work, she has two apprentices to whom she is providing quality training for their future work.
Mariama is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Juaben Ladies’. She is pictured in the middle of the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are small traders or food traders. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy sewing materials such as linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: Mrs. Seakleng Hok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank group consists of 13 members located in Chek village, Kandal province. They will all use their loans for different purpose.
Mrs. Seakleng H. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She and her husband, Mr. Savea Pat, are farmers who own five hectares of land and they work as laborers when they have free time. Currently, it is the growing season but Mrs. Seakleng H. does not have enough money for farming. Therefore, she decided to request a third loan in order to buy rice seed and hire a laborer to plow the field. The couple has four children, three of whom are attending the local school and the youngest of whom is too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and hire a laborer to plow the field

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mr. Kong S. has used his old motorcycle to pick up the passengers for a profit and generate a daily income to support his family’s needs. Another source of family income is provided by his wife, who works cultivating rice on the land next to their house. This couple was married many years ago and has three children, one of whom works in garment factory and other two are students. Kong S. is taking out his loan to purchase a plot of neighboring farmland, well located for farming, on which he will plant a variety of crops.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of neighboring farmland

loans.name: Gulara

texts.en: Gulara A. was born in 1957. She is married and has 3 children. Agayev's family live in the Khachmaz region. She has been in this business for 4 years. She is requesting a loan of 2000 AZN to buy shoes to resell.

loans.use: to buy shoes

loans.name: Razia Maryam Group

texts.en:
Shaima who is the group leader of Razia Maryam. She is married and lives in Kabul Afghanistan. She has made a group of 4 members. Each one of them is busy in different tasks. Shaima wants to take a loan for her son. He sells mobile cards and with this loan he wants to buy more supplies of mobile cards. 

The second member of the Razia Maryam group is Razia. She wants to make a loan for her husband who has a catering shop. With this loan he wants to buy more utensils for his shop. 

Sima, the third member of Razia Maryam group is busy in tailoring. With this loan she wants to buy a new sewing machine for her tailoring business.

The last member of Razia Maryam group is Maryam who has a bead weaving business.  With this loan she wants to buy some velvet cloth and beads for her business.  They all happy from kiva with this program of small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: They want to buy some tools for their business

loans.name: Eliava Candiru Grace Group

texts.en:
Grace C. is twenty-eight years of age and married with three school-aged children. She has dealt with fruits such as mangoes, oranges, etc for three years. 

Grace is using the loan to purchase fruits such as mangoes, oranges, sweet bananas and tomatoes to resell. She is an enterprising business lady whose business dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase fruits such as mangoes, oranges, sweet bananas and tomatoes to resell.

loans.name: Okuambo Ocokoru Baifa Group

texts.en:
Baifa O. is loan group representative. She is thirty-one years of age and married with six children of which four are going to school. She deals in the business of selling Irish potatoes and she has been in this business for over four years. 

Baifa is using the loan to purchase bags of Irish potatoes from the local villages for resale in the Arua town market. The loan will improving her business as she is now stocking supplies of Irish potatoes which will increase her profits. She is a hardworking business woman whose future plan is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase bags of Irish potatoes from local villages to resell in the Arua town market.

loans.name: Wilfreda

texts.en:
Wilfreda M. is from the village of Bangko, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She is 61 years old, is widowed, and has three adult children. Wilfreda owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Wilfreda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. Wilfreda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Okuambo Irene Badaru Group

texts.en:
Irene B. is fifty years of age and is a single businesswoman blessed with four children. She is also looking after two dependents, both schooling.

Irene has dealt in cassava flour since 2006. Due to the competition, she is purchasing quality cassava flour to win the attention of customers. With that, at least, her business is improving and she is even going to put grass on her hut (roofing).

Irene is an active and hardworking woman whose dream is to enlarge her business and perhaps build a house.

loans.use: To purchase quality cassava flour to win the attention of customers

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie B. is from the village of Malibacsan in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Virgie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Virgie plants, harvests, and sells bananas. Virgie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,500.00 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Virgie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. Virgie is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Tim

texts.en:
Tim T. has been operating a grocery business in front of her home for more than three years. She can make around $3.00 per day from her business and she uses her income to manage her family’s living expenses. She also relies on the proceeds from her husband’s taxi. This family has six children; two are married and four are single. Two of the children are employed in a garment factory and the rest are in school. 

Tim T. has gained many valued customers and income because she is skilled in public communication in her village. Recently she sold nearly all of her groceries and she wants to acquire more inventory so she can continue selling. Because the lack of money, Tim T. has decided to talk a $500 loan from Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL), a Kiva field partner.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Samiullah Ahmadzi Group

texts.en:
This is the Samiullah A. Group The group has four members, all of whom are men. The members want to improve their businesses so they have requested a loan of 56000 Afghani. 

Samiullah, the group leader, is a tailor. He owns a shop in which he sews different kinds of clothes. With the loan, he would like to buy more sewing machines, because he has problems with the old ones. He also needs more material to make new and different clothing to sell.

Another member, Abdullah, has a general store. He wants to use the loan funds to buy things that are in high demand in his market but are not available in his shop.

The third member, Nasir, sells second-hand clothes. He would like to improve his business and change it. So, he would like to take a loan to purchase the supplies to do it.

The last member, Zabiullah, does embroidery. He has a small shop where he works and most of his clients like his work.

loans.use: To improve their businesses

loans.name: Purreh

texts.en:
Purreh L. is from the village of Butuay in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old. Purreh is widowed and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Purreh prepares and sells candies and cooked food for daily meals in the local community. Purreh has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Purreh joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Purreh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. Purreh is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase ingredients to make the products that she sells. This will be Purreh's second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make food

loans.name: Eliava Ocokoru Hellen Group

texts.en:
Hellen O. is forty-two years old. She is married and has four children in school. She also cares for two dependents, one of whom goes to school. 

Hellen has been selling food, such as cassava flour, ground nuts, and beans, since 2005. She is using this loan to purchase food to sell. The loan will improve her business and she hopes to do better. Her future hope is to obtain a better structure for her home.

loans.use: To purchase food, such as cassava flour, ground nuts, and beans

loans.name: Eam

texts.en: Mrs. Eam T., age 53, and her husband, Chomroeun, age 28, earn their daily profit by farming a rice crop. In addition, the family also buys bamboo to make baskets to sell. Recently, one of Eam T.'s customers ordered a basket from her, but she doesn't have enough raw materials to make, it. She is looking for a loan to buy bamboo for basket-weaving.

loans.use: To buy bamboo for basket-weaving

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad V. is from the village of Panduma in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 46 years old. Caridad is single and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Caridad owns and operates a specialized retail store where she sells a variety of products such as sugar, shampoo, sardines and other daily-use products in the local community. Caridad has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Caridad joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Caridad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. She use her loan to buy additional products to sell. Caridad is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Caridad's third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions and pay for her children's tuition. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Eliava Adiru Monica Group

texts.en:
Monica A. is twenty-six years old. She is married and has one school-aged child. She also cares for five dependents, three of whom go to school. 

Monica sells food, such as cassava, beans and fruits, and fish.She has been in business for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase food to sell. The loan is expanding her business because it allows her to purchases in large quantities and to stock even more inventory. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose future plan is to own an enterprise.

loans.use: To purchase food to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is 52 years old. She is married and mother of seven children. Currently, she is caring for two other children who are in senior high school. 

Comfort owns and operates a grocery shop where she sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk etc. in the area where she lives. She deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. With two years of trading experience, she wants to use the loan to buy more rice, sugar, vegetable oil, body and hair creams etc. to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve sales to enable her save more for her children's education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline G. is from the village of Alindahaw in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 49 years old. Evangeline is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline sells bread and other food snacks in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Evangeline joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. She used her previous loan to purchase additional products to sell. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Evangeline's second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca P. is from the village of Sto. Niño in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 65 years old. Rebecca is married. To make a living, Rebecca sells clothing in the local community. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rebecca joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rebecca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to expand business. This will be Rebecca's third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena is 44 years old. She is divorced and the mother of three children. She is a very hard-working woman who works to provide for her children. All of her children are in school and her business supports them. 

Abena sells food, such as smoked fish and gari, a couscous-like grain made from grated cassava. She sells gari in bulk in the market. Gari is prepared from milled cassava it is processed through various steps before the gari is ready. Abena prepares gari cereals by herself and distributes them to her customers. 

Abena has a large customer base but she doesn't have enough funds to buy ingredients. She plans to use her loan to buy cereals like gari, smoked fish, and a gari-processing machine. With the loan assistance, she believes she will have all of the resources that she needs and she can realize her dream of providing a better education for her children. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy cereals like gari, smoked fish, and a gari-processing machine.

loans.name: Rea

texts.en:
Rea R. is from the town of Gud in San Isidro. She is 21 years old. Rea is married and has one young child. To make a living, Rea owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Rea has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rea joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rea is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Rea's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eliava Ayikoru Joyce Group

texts.en:
Joyce  A. is a forty-year old enterprising businesswoman. She is married and has five children who go to school. She also cares for one dependent, who is also in school. Joyce lives in the Eliava Village in Arua District.

She has been selling cassava flour for ten years. She is using the loan to purchase bags of cassava flour to sell. Her business is improving and she is earning higher profits. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to build a better house.

loans.use: To purchase bags of cassava flour to sell

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro S. is from the village of Tabo-o in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 51 years old. Pedro is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Pedro provides a "habal-habal" (motorcycle taxi) services to local community members. Pedro has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000.00 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Pedro joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedro has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. Pedro is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase materials needed to provide services. This will be Pedro's second loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide a service

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona B. is from the village of Poblacion in Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 61 years old. Ramona is widowed and has 9 adult children. To make a living, Ramona manufactures and sells nipa huts, houses with a bamboo frame and a thatched roof made from the leaves of the Nipa palm. Ramona has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ramona joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ramona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Ramona is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be Ramona's second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture houses

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen B. is from the village of Palilan in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 23 years old. Karen is married and has one young child. To make a living, Karen provides motorcycle transportation services to local community members. Karen is just starting this business.

In 2009, Karen joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Karen is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to use as additional capital for her business. This will be Karen's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchased spare parts for her motorcycle

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth S., age 30, is a married man but he has no children. To earn a living, he built a medium-sized workshop along the street where he provides his services for a profit. 

Muth S. makes knives out of metal. He always waits to get orders from his customers before making a knife. He also depends on the profit from his wife's poultry-raising business at their home. 

Muth S. gets many orders from his customers, but he can’t make enough knives to serve his customer’s needs due to lack of raw material. Thus, Muth S. has decided to request a loan to purchase metal, from which he will make many sets of knives.

loans.use: To purchase metal to make knives to sell

loans.name: Eliava Aikoru Rose Group

texts.en:
Rose A. is a 34-year-old businesswoman. She is married and has eight children, seven of whom go to school. She also cares for one dependent who is in school.

Rose has been a tailor for ten years. She is using this loan to purchase material to make different clothing designs for her customers. She is able to stock more material, so her business is enabling her pay her children's school fees. The loan is really encouraging her to work and to be a very active woman. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to build a better house.

loans.use: To purchase material to make clothing

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey S. was born in 1944 and was married a long time ago to Mr. Sovann, age 54. They now have eight children. Four of their children are married and have already established new homes, and the remaining four are single and are employed in different occupations. 

To make a living, Srey S. sells a few groceries from her home. She can generate $3 per day to help cover her family’s financial needs. In addition, Srey S. and her husband also make Khmer noodles at home for extra profits. 

Srey S. will use her first loan to build up a grocery inventory to sell. With the the rest of loan, she will plant a rice crop.

Srey S. was busy at her business when the photograph was taken, so her husband appears in the picture in her place.

loans.use: To accumulate a grocery inventory

loans.name: Popal Wazhma Group

texts.en:
Wazhma is the group leader of Popal Wazhma Group. After working hard she made up a group of four members, each one of them busy in a different task.

Wazhma is married and has three children. She is busy in tailoring and wants to buy more cloth for her business.

The second member is Samira who wants to take a loan for her son who has a fresh-fruit cart. With this loan he wants to buy more fresh fruit.

The third member is Aziza who wants to take a loan for her husband. He has a shop selling video CDs and with this loan he wants to complete his stock.

The last member of this group is Karima who is busy in her embroidery business. With this loan she wants to buy a new machine for embroidering.

So therefore, they made a group. They want to continue their businesses and have requested a group loan. Each member needs 10,000 Afghani to further their work and be a good client for Kiva and AFS. Wazhma is sure that they can repay the loan on time and that she can control the whole group. They would like to thank every body that helps with this process of providing loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her tailoring business

loans.name: Akram

texts.en:
Akram is married and has three children. He and his family live in Khachmaz town. 
Akram was born in 1961. He has been in this business for five years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy furniture for re-sale to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy furniture for re- sale

loans.name: Arua Hill Cell Driwaru Juliet Group

texts.en:
D. Juliet is just twenty-two years of age, is single, and is a businesswoman. She deals in bitengi (wax-print cloth worn like a sarong). She has been running this business so far for five months.

Juliet is using the loan to purchase more bitengi from the Congo. She is bringing in real quality wax bitengi to her customers. She is winning market share because the quality wax-print material is causing her business to boom and is increasing her profits.

Juliet is an active and hardworking businesswoman whose future hope is to struggle hard and live a good standard life.

loans.use: To purchase more bitengi from the Congo

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Mrs. C. is 27 years of age, is married, and is the mother of a school-aged child. She works sewing clothes in the garment industry.

Mrs. C.’s husband (shown in the photo) is a military policeman and also a taxi driver. He has been using his older motor as a taxi many years. Unfortunately, his taxi has broken and this has affected his income. To solve the problem, Mrs. C. requests a loan to repair her husband’s old taxi.

loans.use: To repair her husband's old taxi

loans.name: Chon

texts.en:
Chon S. is a determined and hardworking woman who earns a living as a local farmer. She plants rice and some vegetables which she sells. Her husband is a palm-climber, tapping palm juice for sale. The couple has three children who are going to school or to work.

Chon S. will be using her first loan to order rice in bulk from other farmers to resell for additional profit.

loans.use: To order rice in bulk to sell

loans.name: Kebiri A Kadara Anite Group

texts.en:
K. Anite is forty-two years of age, is married with five children schooling, and is looking after ten dependents of whom three are going to school.

Anite has a used-clothes business and she has been operating this business for over fifteen years. She is using the loan to purchase a stock of used clothes to sell.

Anite’s business is expanding at a high rate and she is much willing to pay school fees for her children. Her future hope is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of used clothes to sell

loans.name: Kebiri A Katuma Kadija Group

texts.en:
K. Kadija is a businesswoman, thirty-two years old. She is married with five children of whom four are schooling. She is also looking after one dependent.

Kadija deals in shoes which has been her business for over five years. She is using the loan in her business of selling shoes: that is to say, shoes for children, women and men.

Kadija is encouraging, hardworking and so active. Her dream is to educate her children to university level.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes for her business

loans.name: Enhbaatar

texts.en:
Enhbaatar B. is 30 years old and is not yet married. He lives with his mother in Tuv province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. He currently has a girlfriend and plans on marrying soon.

Enhbaatar has a small farm with nineteen milking cows. He started his farming business in 2007 with only eight milking cows. Since then, his mother helped in his business and he has been able to expand the business by adding eleven more milking cows. As he expanded his small farm, he also added two more full-time employees to take the additional responsibility.

Enhbaatar hopes to expand his farm to have at least fifty milking cows. He says that there is overwhelming demand for milk, especially during cold seasons when the milk price peaks and more than triples that of the summer. He further says that he would like to make his farm an exemplary one in the region.

Enhbaatar requests a loan to purchase more hay and other necessary nutrition for his cows.

loans.use: To purchase more hay and other necessary nutrition for his cows

loans.name: Gavaa

texts.en: Gavaa U. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and 11-year-old daughter in Bayanhongor province, one of Mongolia's southwestern provinces. His daughter is 11 years old and goes to a local secondary school. Gavaa has a small business in wood chopping. He used to work at a local bath house as a mechanist. When he was a mechanist, he chopped wood at home and sold to locals. Since 2006, he left his job to expand his wood chopping business, which was more lucrative than his bath house job. Since the start in 2006, he has already gained some frequent customers who always purchase chopped wood from him. He says that he would like to expand his business by opening a small marketplace where he would be able to sell chopped woods in wholesale in large amounts. He requests a loan to purchase more wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood to sell.

loans.name: Sandagsuren

texts.en: Sandagsuren R. is a 46-year-old herder woman. She and her husband live in the countryside of Tuv province with their livestock, including goats, sheep, horse and cattle. Her husband mostly herds the livestock while Sandagsuren rents a small stall at the local food market where she sells beef and mutton in small pieces. Sandagsuren started retailing beef and mutton in 2002 and has been quite successful: her business capital has increased from 500,000 MNT to 3,500,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT) to date. With the business profit, she was able to financially support her two sons' marriages and pay off her daughter's university tuition and living expense in the city. She notes that she would like to purchase a small, cozy house with running water and indoor toilet in the future. She requests a loan to purchase feed for her livestock and additional beef for the retail business.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her livestock and additional beef for the retail business.

loans.name: Altantsooj

texts.en: Altantsooj is 25 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Zavkhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a Mongolian traditional tent called "ger". His son, who is 7 years old, attends a local secondary school while his daughter, who is 1 years old, has not reached school age yet. His wife is a janitor at a state-owned organization and Altantsooj operates a taxi service in his town. He transports people from Zavkhan province to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Altantsooj started his taxi service business in 2008 and besides his transportation business, he manages a raw material trading business in order to supplement to his earnings. He says, "I am working hard in order to save some money to buy my own house." Altantsooj is requesting a 350,000 tugrug loan to purchase machinery parts for his car and some raw materials, such as sheep and goat skin, for his other business.

loans.use: To purchase machinery parts for his car and some raw materials, such as sheep and goat skin.

loans.name: Ariuntsetseg

texts.en:
Ariuntsetseg is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Dornogobi province, Mongolia. Her daughters, aged 16 and 12, both attend a local high school while her husband is currently unemployed.

Ariuntsetseg operates a grocery trading shop in one of the rooms of her house. She started her business in 2006 by extending her house in order to conduct her business. In the future, she wants to sell not only grocery products but also toiletry and household goods too. She says, "I am planning to build another house that can be used just as a shop as soon as I can earn enough money for my daughters' education."

Ariuntsetseg is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase consumer goods for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Byambajav

texts.en:
Byambajav is 51 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Zavhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent. His son, 18 years old, and daughter, 22 years old, both attend university while his wife is disabled and must stay home.

Byambajav operates a grocery trading shop in his town. He started his business in 2000. His business has been quite successful which has allowed him and his family a better quality of life. With his earnings, he was able to pay the tuition fees for both of his children.

Byambajav is planning to open one more grocery shop in order to increase his sales channels. He is an open-minded and hardworking businessman with lots of plans for the future. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase grocery products for his shop and to pay the tuition fees of his children.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products for his shop and to pay the tuition fees of his children

loans.name: Bayarsaihan

texts.en:
Bayarsaihan is 50 years old and lives with his wife and 20-year-old son in a house in Darhan-Uul province, Mongolia. His son, Erdenebayar, is a university student and Bayarsaihan's wife helps with the family business.

Bayarsaihan operates a door-to-door meal business in his town. His wife is responsible for making the meals at their home and he is responsible for delivering the meals to customers. They make and sell between twenty and thirty meals per day.

Bayarsaihan started his business in 2008 after he incurred too many injuries while working as a plumber for several years. Even though he has been in operation for a short period of time, he is well known amongst his customers and he is planning to expand his business further. For the future, he is planning to have his own food cafe in his town.

Bayarsaihan is a very hardworking man with a good personality. He says, "I want to buy a car with the loan. With my own car I can more easily deliver my products to my customers." He is requesting a 1,300,000 tugrug loan to purchase a car to use in his business.

loans.use: To purchase a car to use in his business

loans.name: Erdenesuvd

texts.en:
Erdenesuvd is a single mother who lives with her three children in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent called “ger”. Her oldest daughter, 19 years old, attends university and her younger daughter and her son, aged 10 and 7, go to a local secondary school.

Erdenesuvd operates a vegetable and dairy retail business in her town. She sells the vegetables that she grows herself. She plants a variety of vegetables in her fields such as potatoes, carrots, cabbage, onions, garlic, etc.

Erdenesuvd started her business in 1998 by borrowing 150,000 tugruks (~100 USD) from Xacbank, Kiva’s partner. In addition to her vegetable trading, she began selling dairy products two years ago. Over the years, she has been able to establish herself in the local business community.

Erdenesuvd is a hardworking and open-minded lady who is trying to better the quality of her children's lives. She says, “I am doing my best in order to provide a happy life for my children.” She is requesting a 1,100,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of dairy products to sell this coming winter season.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of dairy products

loans.name: Umarat

texts.en:
In the photo you can see Umarat who is applying for her second loan from Kiva. Before, she sold chairs but having improved her business she started a fruit and vegetable business.

Now, Umarat needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy fruits and vegetables to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en:
Jargalsaihan is 42 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent called “ger”. Her second son, Ganbaatar, attends university and her youngest son, Ganbyamba, goes to a local high school.

Jargalsaihan operates a clothing retail business in her town with the help of her husband. They sell a variety of clothes that are imported from China. She started her business in 2003. At first she ran her business by herself, but after a while her husband began to help which resulted in an extensive increase in their business. They are well known amongst the neighboring residents because of their high quality and stylish clothes.

For the future, they are planning to expand their product line and build an even stronger customer base. Jargalsaihan is an open-minded lady with good personality. She says, “I am working hard in order to better my children's life.” She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase pants, boots, etc., to sell this winter.

loans.use: To purchase pants, boots, etc. to sell this winter

loans.name: Nasanbayar

texts.en:
