Nasanbayar is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son, aged 5, is in kindergarten and his daughter, 1, has not reached school age yet. His wife operates a clothing trading business in their town.

Nasanbayar manages a taxi service. He transports people to and from Uvurhangai province and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He started his business in 2008 with working capital of 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD). Even after such a short period of business operation, he has managed to establish himself in the business community and is well-known for his excellent driving skills. Now his monthly profit exceeds 900,000 tugrugs (~630 USD).

For the future Nasanbayar is planning to improve both his and his wife's businesses. He is a very careful driver who constantly maintains his car in order to provide a safe service to his customers. He says, “I want to expand my business by fixing my car.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase machinery parts for his car and some clothes for his wife's business.

loans.use: to purchase machinery parts for his car and clothes for his wife's business

loans.name: Kebiri A Onziru Kilara Group

texts.en:
O. Kilara lives in Kebiri Village in Arua district. She is thirty-nine years old and is a single businesswoman blessed with five children of whom one is schooling.

Kilara carries out a grocery business dealing in tomatoes, onions, etc. She is using the loan to purchase more grocery items for her business. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her business

loans.name: Nigeria Group

texts.en:
Jambo (hello) from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania!

This is Dafrosa N. and the Nigeria loan group. Dafrosa is 42 years old, married, and has three children. Her son is the eldest at 21 years old, and her daughters are 17 and 10. All three of them are in school.

Dafrosa is a butcher by trade, and has been in the business since 2007. Her butcher shop opens at 7 a.m. every day, and closes whenever she runs out of meat or the stream of customers has ended. She estimates that she makes about 240,000 Tanzanian shillings per month, or about $180 dollars.

This will be Dafrosa's first loan from Tujijenge. She will use it to purchase more beef ("nyama ya ng'ombe" in Kiswahili), and a refrigerator that will help her preserve meat for longer and therefore reduce the amount she has to throw away. She hopes this will help her increase her profits.

In the photo, Dafrosa is standing in the back row on the left wearing a pink scarf. She is shown with the other members of her group, most of whom are food vendors in nearby markets. The Nigeria loan group thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To buy more beef and a refrigerator

loans.name: Sugarbadam

texts.en:
Sugarbadam is 45 years old and lives in Dornogobi province, Mongolia. She lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent. She is divorced from her husband and her four children are grown and live and work on their own.

Sugarbadam operates a tourist camp and food cafe in her town. In her tourist camp she hosts both foreign and domestic customers during the peak tourist season in the summer. Her customers are very satisfied and have a relaxing time viewing the natural beauty of Dornogobi province.

Sugarbadam started her tourism business in 2007 by renting a ger from her friend. After operating both her tourism business and her food cafe, she has enabled herself to live a better quality life. For the future, she is planning to expand her tourism business in order to help her children and their families.

Sugarbadam says, “My dream is to open a hotel in my town.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase new gers for her tourism business. In the photo, Sugarbadam is shown with her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase new gers in for her tourism business

loans.name: Ulziibayar

texts.en:
D. Uzliibayar is 44 years old and lives with her daughter in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter is 13 years old and currently attends a local secondary school.

Ulziibayar operates a small bakery out of her home, making and selling a variety of baked goods to residents living in the surrounding countryside. She also works at a local insurance company to supplement her income.

Ulziibayar started her bakery seven years ago and has built a stable operation over the years. She says, "I must work hard in order to better my daughter and youngest sister's living conditions."

Ulziibayar has many plans for the future and hopes to one day own her own workplace. She is requesting an 850,000 tugrug  loan to purchase an oven for her bakery and to pay her younger sister's school tuition.

loans.use: To purchase an oven for her bakery and to pay her younger sister's school tuition

loans.name: Jacinto Cell B Akite Harriet Group

texts.en:
A. Harriet is a twenty-two-year-old businesswoman. She carries out a grocery business selling onions, fish, tomatoes, groundnut paste (peanut butter), and so forth and has been in her business for over five years.

Harriet is using the loan to purchase more of these grocery items to sell. She is really willing to improve upon her business for better profits. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children to university level and, more so, to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Byambahishig

texts.en:
Byambahishig is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two teenage children in a house in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Her son and daughter, aged 18 and 14, both attend a local high school while her husband helps Byambahishig with the family business.

Byambahishig operates a grocery retail business out of two rented stalls at a local market. She sells a variety of vegetables such as potatoes, carrots, cabbages, onions, garlic, etc. She started her business in 1996 with working capital of 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD). Since then she has managed her business successfully and established a strong customer base.

With her business earnings Byambahishig was able to buy some land and build a house in 2009 in order to improve her family's quality of life. Moreover, she bought a car for her family use. Now her working capital exceeds 4,000,000 tugrugs (~2800 USD).

Byambahishig is an intelligent businesswoman with a good personality. She says, "I want to improve my business and open my own grocery shop in the future." Byambahishig is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a wide variety of vegetables for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a wide variety of vegetables

loans.name: Club B Candiru Jamira Group

texts.en:
C. Jamira is a hardworking business lady who is 28 years old and runs a drugstore. She is married and blessed with three children who are in school.

She has been operating the drugstore for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase medicines for the drugstore. Her business is improving and, moreover, allowing her to pay the school fees of her children. Her future plan is to purchase a plot of land and see her children through school.

loans.use: To purchase medicines for her drugstore

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia is married with a child. She is 38 years old and sells sarongs at a market in Warri, Delta State. Her husband is a driver and her child attends a private school. With the little profit she makes she helps the family with the school fees.

She hopes for a loan 80,000 Nigerian naira. With the loan, she plans to expand her sarong business, which is now booming. With this kind of business she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to provide a better education for her child. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en:
Ganbaatar is 48 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in a house in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. His oldest daughter, who is 21 years old, is a university student and the youngest, who is six years old, attends a local secondary school. Ganbaatar operates a wooden products business with the help of his wife. He is responsible for making a variety of wooden products such as tables, chairs, and cupboards, while his wife is responsible for decorating and painting the products. 
They started their business in 2000 with working capital of 350,000 tugrugs (~240 USD). Over the years he has expanded and improved his business with working capital now reaching 2,500,000 tugrugs (~1,800 USD). They are well known to residents of their town because of their products' good quality and modern style. With their business profits, they were able to redesign and fix their own home. To supplement their earnings they also began a secondhand clothing retail business in 2004. Now they can fully support all of their family members' needs. He says, "In business one must possess good communication skills." He is requesting a 600,000 tugrug loan to purchase wood for his furniture business.

loans.use: To purchase unprocessed wood

loans.name: Radion

texts.en:
Radion X. was born in 1955. He is married with two children and lives in Khachmaz town.

Radion has been in his taxi business for six years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts for his taxi to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 36-year-old married man with two children. In 2003, he decided to open a library in his town as his own business. Today, he is applying for a loan of $2,100 to buy additional supplies for his shop and to satisfy the needs of his customers.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies for his shop

loans.name: Labeeb

texts.en:
Labeeb is a 62-year-old married man with two children. He is a carpenter, making furniture in Nablus, Palestine, which he has done since 1980. He uses his income to pay for his family's daily expenses and his children's college fees.

Labeeb will use the loan to purchase wood and carpentry tools. With the new profits from his expanded business he plans to reinvest for the expansion of his business.

loans.use: To purchase wood and carpentry tools

loans.name: Husam

texts.en:
Husam is 38 years old, is married, and has six children. He lives in the city of Nablus, Palestine.

Husam owns a small restaurant and wants a loan to purchase a new cooking stove, tables and chairs and to renovate his restaurant. That way, he will be able to increase his income and provide a better life for his family.

Husam is happy with the help Ryada is giving him and he would like to thank those who make the loan possible for him.

loans.use: To purchase a new cooking stove, tables and chairs and to renovate his restaurant

loans.name: Chimedtsogzol

texts.en:
Chimedtsogzol is a 47-year-old widow who lives with her four children in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. She and her children live in a Mongolian nomadic tent called a "ger." Her eldest daughter, 22, attends university, and her eldest son, 20, is in the army; her younger son, 17, is disabled while the youngest son, 9, goes to a local secondary school.

Chimedtsogzol supports her family by operating a door-to-door grocery and dairy product retail business in her town. She started her business in 2000 with working capital of 80,000 tugrugs (~56 USD). Over the years of business operation she gained much experience and is well known among her customers. Now her working capital exceeds 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD). She attributes her business success to her good accounting and communication skills. She says, "For the future I am planning to expand my business further, but my main business goal is to provide quality products to my customers." She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase dairy products to sell this coming winter when dairy products become scarce and prices for these products rise.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products

loans.name: Ibraheem

texts.en: Ibraheem, a 46-year-old married man with six children, comes from Nablus City, Palestine. He has owned a tile-polishing shop since 2008. Today, Ibraheem is requesting to borrow US$3,000 to purchase an additional tile-polishing machine to be able to satisfy the demands of this market.

loans.use: Purchase an additional tile-polishing machine

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en: Ziad is 44 years old and lives with his wife and eight children. He is an entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuffs, including sweets, soft drinks, and juice, in a grocery store that he owns. Ziad needs a loan of US$2,000 to be able to increase the stock of goods in his store. He is ready to work hard and make sacrifices to become an even more successful entrepreneur. Both Ziad's perseverance and clear vision will help him succeed in his small business.

loans.use: Increase the stock of goods in his store

loans.name: Club B Candiru Kadija Group

texts.en: C. Kadija is a 48-year-old widow blessed with six children, of whom one child is going to school. She is involved in an art and craft business and has been doing this creative work since the year 2000. She is using this loan to purchase art and craft materials for making mats, hats, etc. She is a hard-working business woman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase art and craft materials for making mats, hats, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Funding of market garden business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of general grocery products

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is excited about taking out a Kiva loan. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria, where she sells bed sheets at the market. She is 29 years old and married, with five children. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more lightly-used bed sheets to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more used bed sheets to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy supplies of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of baking products

loans.name: Apolline

texts.fr: Madame A. Apolline est une femme âgée de 36 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle habite avec sa famille à Kpélé-Atimé. Elle tient une baraque dans laquelle elle vend les produits de l’alimentation générale. Avec ce crédit, elle se déplacera sur Kpalimé, une ville plus grande que son village de Kpélé-Atimé, où elle s’approvisionne en produits d’alimentations générales qu’elle revend à un bon prix dans sa localité et de ses environ. Les bénéfices qu’elle dégagera lui permettront d’améliorer le quotidien de sa famille et de payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs Apolline A. is a 36-year old woman who is married with four children. She lives with her family in Kpélé-Atimé. She has a hut in which she sells general grocery products. With this loan, she will go to Kpalimé, a larger town than the village of Kpélé-Atimé, where she will stock up with general grocery products that she will sell on at a good price in her village and the surrounding area. The profits that she makes will allow her to improve the daily living conditions of her family and to pay for her children's schooling.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and resale of general grocery products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Jacinto Cell A Rukia Candiru Group

texts.en: Rukia C. is the group representative of this group in Jacinto Cell. She is 35 years old and married with seven children, of whom five are going to school. She is operating a charcoal selling business, which she has been doing for over three years. She will be using the loan to purchase and transport charcoal from different villages to the market. She is improving: previously she had been purchasing ten bags of charcoal, but at present she buys twenty or more. She is hard-working and has a positive attitude. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and transport it to market.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To sell the local drink sodabi

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is 52 years old and is a widow with seven children. She lives in Benin City and is a focused, hard worker.

Victoria has machines that she uses to grind beans, tomatoes, pepper and maize for her customers. The demand for her services are high in her community. She has been in this business for a long time even before her husband passed away. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase a grinding machine. She says thank you to all lenders.

Victoria is a committed LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine

loans.name: Ombizevua Cell A Ondoru Molly Group

texts.en:
O. Molly is the president of her group. She is aged forty years and is married with six children of whom four are schooling. More so, she is looking after three dependents of whom one is going to school.

Molly has dealt in provisions such as cassava flour, etc., for over fifteen years. She is using the loan to purchase more provisions to sell. The loan will improve her business which is her aim.

Molly is a courageous businesswoman whose dream is to construct a better house for her family and to educate her children to university level.

loans.use: To purchase provisions such as cassava flour, etc., to sell

loans.name: Jacinto Cell A Candiru Farida Group

texts.en:
C. Farida is thirty-two years old and is the cashier of this group. She is married with seven children of whom six are going to school. She is also taking care of one dependent who is going to school too.

Farida operates a business selling breakfast coffee, black tea, milk tea, bread, boiled cassava and a mixture of maize and beans as accompaniments. She is using the loan to purchase cups, flasks and sugar bowls as well as tea ingredients, boiled maize, bread, boiled cassava, and so forth.

Farida is an active businesswoman who is struggling to move on with life, as in “live a changed life”. Her future hope is to work very hard to get profits to enable her to obtain a plot of land and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and supplies for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sewing machines

loans.name: Club Cell A Zaituni Ismail Group

texts.en:
Zaituni I. is is the president of her group. She is thirty-eight years old, is married, and is blessed with five children, all schooling.

Zaituni offers tailoring services and has been in this business for over six years. She is using the loan to purchase material for making different customers’ designs. She is buying the material (bitengi: pieces of cloth worn like sarongs) from the Congo (Zaire).

Zaituni is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase another sewing machine to make more profits. She wants to purchase a plot of land, too, and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase material for making different customers' designs

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
K. Charles is a businessman, thirty-five years old. He has a cosmetics shop located four kilometers away from Zanna. He started his business six years ago.

Charles is using the loan to purchase cosmetics such as jelly, crème, lotions, etc., to expand his business. His future dream is to buy another plot of land.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: David 1 Group

texts.en:
Mirla, 21, is a borrower who lives near La Romana in the Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, David, and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.
Mirla and her husband have three young children that live at home. Life around La Romana can be difficult, and conditions are typically quite poor. Access to electricity is extremely limited, potable running water is nonexistent, and health care is inadequate at best. Despite these and other difficulties, Mirla runs a small business out of her home making quilts and sheets for her neighbors and friends. She will be using this loan to purchase more fabric and thread.
This is Mirla’s second loan with Esperanza International. She is very appreciative of the new access to loans, and has already seen improvements in her home from her business profits. With continued profits, she hopes to purchase a new bed for her daughter as well as a washing machine to give her more free time during the day. Mirla plans to work hard so that her business can continue growing, and eventually she hopes to make enough money to secure a good education for all her children. Thank you for lending to Mirla and the David group!

loans.use: To purchase fabric to make quilts and sheets

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is 48 years old. She is a widow with six children. She is a client of Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She sells used clothing to make a living. She supports her children’s education. She purchases her used clothing from Lagos to sell in Benin City. She has been in this business for a long time. 


She is requesting a loan of 40,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more used clothing to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothing to sell

loans.name: Libasse

texts.fr:
Monsieur Libasse N. est un jeune homme de29 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 4mois et 4 ans. Il est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-Imcec a Yoff depuis janvier 2009 mais n’a jamais bénéficié de prêt. Il est spécialisé dans l’électronique et la maintenance informatique. Il s’active dans son activité depuis 2006.C’est une activité qu’il a choisi par passion. Il a commence a l’exercer avant même de subir une formation dans ce domaine. Son plus grand bonheur c’est lorsqu’il enregistre un succès pendant ses séances de dépannage. Monsieur N. dispose d’un scooter pour faciliter ses déplacements. Il sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs. Une partie de l’argent est prévue pour l’achat de matériels électroniques tels que appareil de mesure, appareil digital, fer a souder, pompe a dessouder et caisse a trousse. L’autre partie du financement servira a changer les pièces défectueuses de son scooter. Ce sont les revenus qu’il gagne qui lui permettent d’entretenir sa famille.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.²
texts.en:
Mr Libasse N. is a young man aged 29, married and the father of three children aged between 4 months and 4 years. He has been a member of the Yoff branch of the microfinance institution U-IMCEC since January 2009, but never took out a loan. He specialized in electronics and computer repair. This is an activity he chose in 2006 because he had a passion for electronics, even before he began his training. He becomes very happy when he is successful with a troubleshooting assignment. He owns a scooter for his travels.

Mr N. applies for a loan of 250,000 CFA francs. He will use part of the loan to buy electronic equipment, such as a measuring device, a digital device, a soldering iron, an unsoldering pump and a toolkit. The remaining funds will be used to repair his scooter. The income from this activity enables him to provide for his family.

Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC – with the positive support of lenders – succeeds in supporting people in revenue-generating activities which promote valuable socioeconomic development.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in electronic tools and repair his scooter

loans.name: Fight For Shameness Group

texts.en:
These are the members of the Fight for Shameness group in the city of Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. These small-scale entrepreneurs have applied through SMT for a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to buy more goods for their businesses. This way they can increase their sales; earn higher profits and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group is Randa A. on the right side of the photo. Randa is 39 years old and was born in Bo city in southern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and they have 3 children – one in college and two in secondary school. Randa sells gari (food made out of ground cassava roots), magi (used to sweeten sauces), onions, tomatoes, soaps and other goods. She has been in this business for two years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy soap, gari, onions and tomatoes.

loans.use: Buy soap, gari, onions and tomatoes

loans.name: Violetas Group

texts.en:
The communal bank VIOLETAS is maD. up of a board of directors: The President is Sra. Juana who sells breakfast and soft drinks at a taxi stop on Trufi Route 101 (trufis are taxis that operate like buses, with fixed routes). She lives in her own house with her three children, in the basin region. She maintains the home herself.

The Secretary is Sr. Rene Que who has been in the taxi business (Route 101) for 5 years. He works every day of the week and lives in his father-in-law's house in the Sausalito region with his wife and two children.

The Treasurer is Sra. Dayana who has been running a neighborhood store for 10 years. Sra. Dayana sells every day, and lives in a house with her husband and daughter in the Colquiri region. The group is very dynamic and responsable, and they support each other and work together.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of working capital

loans.name: Frontier Group

texts.en:
Here are the members of the Frontier Group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. These entrepreneurs are seeking a loan of SLL 2,000,000 (or SLL 500,000 for each) to enable them to expand their businesses. With this loan they will be able to buy more goods for their businesses; increase sales and consequently improve their standard of living.

Mabinty B. is the leader of this group. Mabinty is 36 years old and is married to a miner with 3 children who are attending primary school. For 3 years now, Mabinty has sold cooked foo-foo (food made out of ground cassava roots). With her share of this loan, she will buy cooking ingredients such as foo-foo, palm-oil, fish, pepper, meat, etc. 

(Pasted on the left side of the photo is a group member who was not available for a group photo)

loans.use: Buy cooking ingredients such as foo-foo, palm-oil, fish, pepper, meat, etc.

loans.name: Sabanoh Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Sabanoh Group. Sabanoh group members are petty businesspeople in the city of Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to give a boost to their businesses. With this loan, they can add more goods to their stalls. Consequently, this will attract more customers to their businesses, and they will make more sales and better profit, thereby improving their living conditions.

The leader of this group is John T. who is on the left in the photo. John Thollley, 45 years old, was born in a place called Makali, in northern Sierra Leone. His wife is a businesswoman and 3 of their children are attending school – 1 in secondary school, 2 in primary school; the eldest is now on his own. John makes a living through selling flour, rubber bowls, and cups. He is been doing this business for 5 years now. With his share of this loan, he will buy bags of flour, dozens of rubber bowls, and dozens of cups to add to his current stock.

loans.use: Buy bags of flour, dozens of rubber bowls, and dozens of cups to add to his current stock

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Madame Fatou T. est une femme âge de 45 ans, mariée,  mère de 6 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 13 et 26ans. Elle habite dans le quartier de Ngaparou dans le village de Yoff. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC de Yoff depuis janvier 2009 et a déjà bénéficié d’un prêt antérieur. Elle évolue dans le commerce plus precisement dans la vente de biscuits qu’elle achète a l’usine depuis plus de 15 ans. C’est par passion de cette activité qu’elle a délaissé l’aviculture pour s’orienter vers la vente de biscuits. Son objectif est d’être  indépendante financièrement  afin qu’elle puisse satisfaire ses propres besoins. Pour Madame T. ce qui l’intéresse le plus dans son occupation c’est son caractère lucratif. Elle sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs pour l’achat de sac de biscuits diversifies .Son souhait est d’accroitre son chiffre d’affaire et en même temps ses bénéfices. Elle participe dans la gestion  familiale en couvrant une partie des dépensés quotidiennes.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs Fatou T., aged 45, is married and the mother of six children aged between 13 and 26. She lives in the neighborhood of Ngaparou in the town of Yoff. She has been a member of the Yoff branch of the microfinance institution U-IMCEC since January 2009 and was granted already one previous loan. She has been a seller of cookies for over 15 years. She buys her supply at the factory. She abandoned her previous poultry farming activity, because she had a passion for selling. Her goal is to be financially independent, so that she can provide herself for her own needs. This is why the lucrative aspect of her business matters a great deal to her.

Mrs T. applies for a loan of 250,000 CFA francs to buy bags of miscellaneous cookies. She wants to increase both her turnover and her earnings. She participates in the family charges and contributes to the daily household expenses.

Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC – with the positive support of lenders – succeeds in supporting people in revenue-generating activities which promote valuable socioeconomic development.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Sol Naciente Group

texts.es:
El banco de Emprendimiento "SOL NACIENTE" se encuentra en su cuarto ciclo, el cual esta conformado por personas responsables y trabajadoras, este grupo esta representada por las siguientes socias: Angela quien es la lider y fundadora del grupo, tiene el negocio de peluches en la calle San Martin. Esta casada y tiene 4 hijos pero que actualmente vive con 2 ya que las mayores son casadas y viven de manera independiente. 
Como Tesorera esta la  Sra Rosario esta casada y tiene 3 hijos pequeños ella tiene el negocio de venta de gelatinas ambulando por la cancha(mercado central de la ciudad de Cochabamba), y la secretaria es la Sra. Ilda  quien tambien tiene el negocio de venta de peluches tiene 3 hijos y es una persona activa.
texts.en:
The communal bank "SOL NACIENTE" (Rising Sun) is in its fourth cycle, and is made up of responsible and hardworking people. This group is represented by the following members: Angela is the leader and founder of the group. She has a stuffed animals business on San Martin Street. She is married and has four children but currently she lives with two of them since the older ones are married and live on their own.

Sra. Rosario is the Treasurer, and she is married and has three small children. She has a street stand that sells gelatin in La Cancha (the central market of the city of Cochabamba). The Secretary is Sra. Ilda who also has a business selling stuffed animals. She has three children and is an active person.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase in working capital

loans.name: Baker's Group

texts.en: These are local entrepreneurs in the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone who have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to boost their businesses. They named their group Baker’s Group, after the group leader’s profession. The leader of this group is David K. on the left in the photo. He was born in Makoloh, in northern Sierra Leone.  The 42-year-old David K. has been baking and selling bread for over 7 years now. This father of two secondary and two primary school children will use his share of this loan to buy bags of flour, yeast, and salt.

loans.use: Buy bags of flour, yeast, and salt

loans.name: Tagbaneh Group

texts.en: These are members of the Tagbaneh group in the city of Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking loans of SLL 1,200,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. In the middle of the photo is Fatu K. who is the leader of this group. Fatu was born in Makeni about fifty-eight years ago; she is a widow with eight children. Six of Fatu’s children are already grown-ups and two are attending secondary school. Fatu has been a businesswoman for many years. She sells market-food – rice, palm oil, onions, salt, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy  the above-mentioned items in larger quantity.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice, palm oil, onions, salt

loans.name: Lelis

texts.es: El Sr. Lelis tiene la actividad de carpintero, su taller se encuentra en la casa de la suegra que esta ubicada en la zona de ovejuyo, actividad con la cual sustenta a toda su familia que esta compuesta por 4 hijos y esposa quien realiza trabajos del hogar, se pudo comprobar en la visita domiciliaria que  el cliente vive modestamente ya que el trabajo que realiza solo le alcanza para mantener a su familia y cubrir sus prestamos, demostrando puntualidad y responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Lelis is a carpenter. His shop is in his mother-in-law’s house, which is located in the Ovejuno area. This activity supports his whole family, which is comprised of four children and his wife. His wife does the household chores. It was evident during the home visit that the client lives modestly. His work only suffices to support the family and cover his loans. He demonstrates punctuality and responsibility.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw material (wood)

loans.name: Mame Marieme Thior

texts.fr:
Mame Marieme Thior G. est une femme  de 42 ans  mariée et mère de 7 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 3 et 23 ans. Elle habite à Dagoudane un des quartiers de Yoff. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse depuis septembre 2009 et n’a jamais bénéficié de crédit Elle pratique le commerce depuis 2008.L’activité qu’elle a choisi par simple passion est la vente de tissus et parfums. Et ce qui l’intéresse le plus c’est la réalisation de bénéfices Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs qui sera destine a l’achat des marchandises précitées. Avec ses bénéfices elle parvient a apporter un soutien financier a la famille en assurant une partie des dépenses quotidiennes dans le foyer..
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mame Marieme Thior G. is a 42-year old woman who is married and has seven children, whose ages range from three to 23 years old. She lives in Dagoudane, one of the neigborhoods of Yoff. She has been a member of the savings bank since September 2009 and has never taken out a loan. She has been trading since 2008. The activity she has chosen simply because it is a passion for her is the sale of materials and perfumes. What interests her most is making profits. She is asking for a loan of 150,000 francs which will be used to buy the above-mentioned goods. With the profits she makes she will be able to provide financial support for her family by covering part of the daily household expenses. As part of its ongoing vision to participate actively in the battle against poverty, U-IMCEC, with the backing of its lenders, is successfully providing support to people in order for them to carry out profitable revenue generating activities; this in turn is contributing to a welcome socio-economic development.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of working capital

loans.name: Javier

texts.es: EL Sr. JAVIER SE DEDICA AL TRANSPORTE PUBLICO, EL TIENE UN TRUFI, ACTIVIDAD CON LA QUE SOSTIENE A SU FAMILIA, QUE ESTA COMPUESTA POR DOS HIJOS PEQUEÑOS Y QUE ESTAN ESTUDIANDO EN LA ESCULA FISCAL POR LA ZONA, LA ESPOSA COLABORA CON LOS INGRESOS PARA EL HOGAR CON TRABAJOS EVENTUALES COMO VENDEDORA DE DIFERENTES PRODUCTOS EN DISTINTAS EMPRESAS, LA FAMILIA ES MUY TRABAJADORA Y RESPONSABLE CON SUS OBLIGACIONES .
texts.en:
Javier works in public transportation. He has a Trufi (minibus), and with it he is able to support his family, including 2 small children who are studying at the local public school. His wife contributes to the earnings of the household through temporary jobs selling different products from various companies. This family is very hardworking and responsible with their obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: maintenance for minibus

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena is a 36-year-old woman who is married with one child who is currently in school. She lives with her family at Effiduase in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Abena is a food vendor, she serves rice and stew in the community where she lives. Abena as she is known by many in the town has been in food production for fifteen years now. She sells at a strategic location in the community but she has low a working capital to utilize that advantage and opportunity. She works all day but still she is unable to achieve more to increase her output.

Abena wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of meat and bags of rice so as to produce in larger quantities and increase her efficiency. She believes this will help expand her operations to raise more income to support her husband in providing support for her child’s education.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat, firewood etc.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 29, married, and a mother of two. Both her children are currently in school. She lives with her family in a community in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works tirelessly in supporting her husband in taking care of the children. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood.

She is a very skillful and a talented hair dresser, and for that reason many people visit her salon. She has two years experience and also has three apprentices. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like wigs, pomade, shampoo, activators, hair dryer machines, etc. to serve her customers well. She would be grateful for your assistance and support.

loans.use: To buy hair products and supplies

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es: LA SRA. ISABEL ES CLIENTE MUY ANTIGUA QUE TIENE SU TIENDA D. BARRIO EN UN DOMICILIO QUE  ES ALQUILADO, LA SRA. ISABEL TIENE 62 AÑOS D. EDAD Y ES BASTANTE TRABAJADORA Y RESPONSABLE SE VE QUE TIENE MUCHA ENERGIA PARA SEGUIR TRABAJANDO PARA SOSTENERSE, EL ESPOSO TIENE LA ACTIVIDAD D. TRANSPORTISTA ASALARIADO ACTIVIDAD CON LA QUE AYUDA A LOS GASTOS DEL HOGAR YA QUE SOLO SON LOS DOS QUE VIVEN EN EL HOGAR.
texts.en:
Isabel has been a client of Emprender for a long time. She has a neighborhood store in her rented home. Isabel is 62 years old and is very hardworking and responsible; she has a lot of energy to continue working to support herself. Her husband is a salaried worker in the transportation sector, and he also helps to cover the household expenses since there are only two of them that live in the home.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 56, married, and the mother of six. Two of her children are in school while the rest are working. She is very resourceful for her family in providing food and paying bills. She is a farmer and food vendor, selling kenkey with fried fish taking with pepper sauce. (Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and taken with hot pepper and fried fish.)

She sells kenkey in the morning and in the afternoon. She has many customers since many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey for breakfast, lunch, and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children’s education.

loans.use: For raw materials and firewood

loans.name: Anta

texts.fr: Anta S. est une femme de 67 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle teint une boutique où elle vend diverses denrées alimentaires. Son objectif est de renforcer son activité, d’augmenter son épargne et de mieux prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Anta S. is a 67-year old woman who is married with six children. She has a shop where she sells various foodstuffs. Her objective is to strengthen her business, to increase her savings and to be able to take better care of her family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To keep a shop selling various products

loans.name: Khaïry

texts.fr: Khaïry N. est une jeune femme mariée de 36 ans, mère de 5 enfants. Elle s’active dans le commerce de tissu et aimerait augmenter ses revenus. Ce prêt lui permettra d’augmenter son épargne et de prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Khairy N. is a young married woman who is 36 years old and has five children. She is active in the sale of cloth and would like to increase her income. This loan would allow her to increase her savings and support her family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of cloth and incense

loans.name: Vine Group

texts.en:
James, who works as a trader, is 41, married, and the father of three. All his children are in school. He is a very resourceful father in caring for his children. He supports them through the sale of used shoes. Used shoes are a very big market in Ghana as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Moreover, second-hand shoes are seen as having quality and durability compared to new ones found in stores. 

Therefore selling of used shoes has created market for many Ghanaians like James. He takes his stock from Greater Accra of Ghana and has been in business for four years now. He wants to use the loan to buy more shoes to increase his inventory. He believes this loan would help him to save more for his children’s education and also to rent a store to trade in.

He is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Vine’. He is the only man in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are small traders and food sellers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy used shoes in bulk

loans.name: Mbarka

texts.fr: Mbarka F. est une femme mariée de 34ans, mère de 3 enfants. Elle s’active dans le commerce de produits cosmétiques. Son souhait est d’augmenter son capital dans le but d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille
texts.en:
Mbarka F. is a married woman who is 34 years old and has three children. She is active in the sale of cosmetics. She would like to increase her capital in order to improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of cosmetics

loans.name: Salvation Group

texts.en:
Aba is 38, married, and has two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her family at Cape Coast in the Central region of Ghana. She has been a baker for six years who uses flour for her production. In spite of the challenges she faces, she bakes bread, cake, meat pie, chips, etc. and sells at retail to her customers. She sells by herself in the market center, and people also take bulk delivery bread from her.

Her only problem now has to do with adequate funds to buy raw materials as prices are going up. She requests a loan support to remain in business. With the loan she believes she can provide for her family and most especially her children's education.

Aba is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Salvation’. She is the one sitting second from left in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are small traders and food sellers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and provide peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for food production

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Madame Fatou D. est une femme de 44 ans qui habite a Ndeugagne un des quartiers de Yoff. Elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 12 et 26 ans. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC a Yoff depuis juillet 2009 et n’a jamais sollicite de crédit. Elle est connue dans la vente de Dieumbes, masque, habits d’art, poissons fumes qu’elle exporte a destination de Paris. Elle évolue dans ce secteur depuis 1984.C’est surtout son mari ancien employé d’Air Afrique qui l’a motive a faire ce choix d’activité car il lui offrait périodiquement le billet. Ce qui l’intéresse le plus dans son activité  ce sont les voyages qu’elle effectue et les bénéfices qu’elle réalise. Elle vend surtout sur commande. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs destine a l’achat de certains produits commandes et a assurer son argent de poche. Grâce aux profits gagnes elle assure la scolarité de ses enfants.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs Fatou D. is a 44-year old woman who lives in Ndeugagne, one of the neighborhoods of Yoff. She is married and has eight children, whose ages range from 12 to 26 years old. She has been a member of the Yoff savings bank - which belongs to the U-IMCEC mutual loan and savings union - since July 2009 and has never taken out a loan. She is known for the sale of "Diembe" drums, masks, handcrafted clothing and smoked fish which she exports to Paris. She has been developing her business in this area since 1984. It is above all her husband, a former employee of Air Africa, who encouraged her to take up this activity because he was able to offer her a ticket from time to time. What interests her most in her business is the trips she makes and the profits she earns. She sells mainly to order. She is asking for a loan of 500,000 francs which will be used for the purchase of certain products she has ordered and to give her some pocket money. Thanks to the profits she makes she can cover the costs of her children's schooling. As part of its ongoing vision to participate actively in the battle against poverty, U-IMCEC, with the backing of its lenders, is successfully providing support to people so that they can carry out lucrative revenue generating activities; this in turn contributes to a welcome socio-economic development.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of working capital

loans.name: The Land Of Rose Group

texts.en: Rita is a 47 year-old married mother of three.  All of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a commercially dominated community. Rita trades in meat. She sells on a table-top at the local market. She is the leader of a trust bank group called The Land of Rose. The members of the group are mainly traders. They are hard working, trust themselves, and want the loan to invest into their businesses. Rita, the group leader, is seated second from left in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy food for resale

loans.name: Beatriz Orieta

texts.es: La Señora Beatriz se dedica a la venta de cosmeticos, desde hace ya varios años, tambien da clases de aerobicos como instructora  en un gimnacio, Ella es soltera, vive en la casa de su madre, donde ayuda bastante en los gastos de su casa. Este credito lo utilizara para comprar una variedad de perfumes y cosmeticos para la venta en estas fiestas de navidad y fin de año. Ella ha demostrado ser una buena clienta y muy cumplida en sus pagos, ella ya esta en una 4º secuencia con la Institucion.
texts.en:
Beatriz has been selling cosmetics for several years. She also gives aerobic classes in a gym. She is single, and lives in her mother’s house where she helps quite a bit with the household expenses. She will use the loan to buy a variety of perfumes and cosmetics to sell for the Christmas and New Year’s parties. She has demonstrated herself to be a good client who makes her payments well. She is in her fourth cycle with the Institution.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy perfumes and cosmetics

loans.name: Marème

texts.fr: Marème M. est âgée de 55 ans, mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle commercialise divers produits alimentaires comme le lait,le cucre et l'huile. Son objectif est de renforcer son capital.
texts.en:
Marème M., 55, is married and the mother of one child. She sells various foodstuffs such as milk, sugar, and oil. Her objective is to bolster her working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling various foodstuffs

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou D. est une dame de 49 ans, mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle s’active dans le commerce de divers produits. Elle souhaite avec ce prêt, renforcer son capital et mieux subvenir aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
Fatou D., 49, is married and the mother of 8 children. She sells various products. She wishes to use this loan to bolster her working capital and better support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling various products

loans.name: Akoma Kor Group

texts.en: Louisa is a 43-year-old married mother of four children. All of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mostly commercial community. Louisa is a professional caterer. She takes orders and prepares food for clients. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Akoma kor’, literally meaning one heart. The members of the group are mainly traders. They are hard working, trust themselves and want the loan to invest in their businesses. Louisa is standing at the back in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy ingredients

loans.name: Marbely Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Marbely F. se dedica a trabajar diariamente en el municipio san Rafael del sur. Esta solicitando un crédito para invertirlo en la compra de materiales de construcción tales como zinc. Bloque, cemento y piedrín con el propósito de beneficiar a sus 4 hijos en edad escolar.
Es importante destacar  que este cliente anteriormente ha recibido dos créditos con Ceprodel los cuales lo ha utilizado para mejorar su vivienda para brindarles un techo digno a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Señora Marbely F. works every day in the town of San Rafael del Sur. She is requesting a loan to put towards the purchase of construction materials, such as zinc, cinder blocks, cement, and stone, for the purpose of improving her home for her 4 school-age children. It is important to emphasize that Señora F. has received two loans from Ceprodel in the past, which she also used to improve her home, providing it with a decent roof to cover her children.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de materiales de construcción

loans.name: Ouleymatou

texts.fr: Ouleymatou S. est une femme de 55 ans, mariée et mère 9 enfants. Elle fait du petit commerce vestimentaire. Son objectif est d’augmenter son capital et de prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Ouleymatou S., 55, is married and the mother of 9 children. She has a little clothing sales business. Her objective is to grow her working capital and support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: have a little clothing business

loans.name: St. Michael Group

texts.en: Esther is 28 years old. She is single and has no children. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a mostly commercial community. Esther is a trader. She trades in printed fabrics. She hawks and treks to sell. Esther is the leader of a trust bank group called St. Michael. The members of the group are mainly traders. They are hard working, trust themselves and want the loan to invest in their businesses. Esther, the group leader, is second from left in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Ndiawa

texts.fr: Ndiawa D. est mariée, 34 ans et mère d’un enfant. Elle fait de la teinture, de la couture et du tissage de pagne. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour pourvoir augmenter son capital afin de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa familles.
texts.en:
Ndiawa D. is 34 years old, married with one child. She dyes cloth, sews, and weaves cloth.for "pagnes". She is requesting this loan so that she can increase her working capital and better meet the needs of her family.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Dye cloth, sew, and weave "pagne" cloth

loans.name: Service To God Group

texts.en: Adriana is a 34-year-old married mother of four children. All of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mostly commercial community. Adriana trades in bags and underwear for ladies. She hawks and treks to sell. Adriana is the leader of a trust bank group called Service to God. The members of the group are mainly traders. They are hard working, trust themselves and want the loan to invest in their businesses. Adriana is the one standing in the group photograph.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Gade

texts.fr: Gade S. est une dame de 50 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle s’active dans le petit commerce de tissus, de chaussures et de parfum. Elle aimerait avec ses revenus assurer ses charges familiales.
texts.en:
Gade S. is a 50-year-old woman. She is married, and mother of five children. She is active in selling cloth, shoes, and perfume. With her income she seeks to cover family expenses.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: small retail business

loans.name: Amina

texts.fr: Amina F. est une femme mariée de 54 ans et mère de 3 enfants. Elle commercialise des produits halieutiques. Son objectif est de renforcer son capital afin de mieux subvenir aux dépenses quotidiennes de sa famille.
texts.en:
Amina F. is a 54-year-old woman, married with three children. She markets fish products. Her objective is to reinforce her working capital so that she can better meet the daily expenses of her family.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Marketing fish products

loans.name: Yaye Fatou

texts.fr: Yaye Fatou N. est âgée de 55 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle fait du petit commerce divers produits. Elle compte, avec les revenus générés, augmenter son épargne et prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Yaye Fatou N., 55, is married and the mother of 4 children. She has a little business selling various products. With the income she generates, she intends to put aside more money and support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling various products

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
Salina is twenty-two years old, is single and has no child. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a commercially dominated community.

Salina works hard to provide for herself. She is a trader, trading in textiles such as linen. She hawks to sell in her community (goes door-to-door) and also treks to other towns to sell.

Salina procures the goods from Accra. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure textiles in bulk.

loans.use: To buy textiles in bulk

loans.name: Pablo

texts.es: El señor Mejía se dedica a la actividad de reparación de llantas de vehículos camiones buses y otras reparaciones. Actualmente está solicitando un crédito para la compra de materiales de trabajo tales como neumáticos llantas herramientas para el enderezado de rines. Es importante destacar su experiencia de más de 22 años en la actividad lo cual lo hace tener clientela numerosa por ser una zona de mucha actividad de transporte ya que está cerca a una empresa productora de cemento.
texts.en:
Mr. M. makes a living by repairing truck and bus tires, as well as other repairs. Currently he is requesting a loan for the purchase of work materials such as inner tubes, tires, and tools for straightening rims. It is important to emphasize his experience of more than 22 years in this activity, which has earned him a large clientele, especially because he works in a zone with a lot of transportation activity, near a company that produces cement.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase work materials

loans.name: Raky

texts.fr: Raky S. est une dame de 56 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle vend des habits d’enfants et divers effets de toilette. Son objectif est d’augmenter son capital avec les revenus générés et de mieux subvenir aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
Raky S., 56, is married and the mother of two children. She sells children's clothing and various toiletries. Her objective is to grow her working capital with the income she generates and to better support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: clothing and toiletries sales

loans.name: Dios Es Amor Group

texts.es:
El grupo Dios es Amor está conformado por Adelina  A., Inés O. y Yolanda L. Padilla, tres mujeres trabajadoras. Ellas son un ejemplo a seguir ya que  todos los días desde muy tempranas horas laboran sin descanso para que en la mesa de sus hogares no falte el pan. 

Adelina realiza comidas típicas donde su especialidad son los nacatamales, comida ha base de masa, cerdo, arroz, chiltoma, chile, papa, tomate entre otros ingredientes. Este se come preferiblemente los fines de semana acompañado de pan o tortilla y café. 

Su compañera Inés Orosco tiene una pequeña pulpería pero está es aseada, ordenada y bien surtida con los productos de consumo y necesidad.  Mientras Yolanda L. Padilla tiene un modesto salón de belleza el cual está tiene una estructura adecuada y cuenta con indumentos necesarios para realizar su trabajo.
texts.en:
The Dios es Amor (God is Love) group is formed by Adelina A., Inés O. and Yolanda L. Padilla, three working women. They are contiuously at work every day from very early in the morning, working without rest so that the tables in their houses do not lack bread.

Adelina makes typical dishes. Tamales are her speciality. The basis of this dish is dough, pork, rice, peppers, potatoes, and tomatoes, among other ingredients. This is eaten, preferably on weekends, accompanied by bread or tortillas, and coffee.

Her colleague Inés Orosco has a small grocery store, but this is tidy, organized, and well stocked with consumer products and necessities. Yolanda L. Padilla has a modest beauty salon which is in an adequate structure. She needs necessary clothing to carry out her work.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of necessary ingredients like dried grains, dough, pork, etc.

loans.name: El Aguacate Group

texts.es:
El grupo El Aguacate está integrado por Silvia L. quien vende comida ella empezó su negocio por la necesidad y la demanda que visualizo que tenían lo trabajadores de las empresas aledañas a su casa de adquirir alimentos. Mientras sus compañeras Eloisa L. y Miriam V. comercializan ropa de diferentes estilos.  

Ellas desean iniciar el nuevo año con trabajo, fuerza y la esperanza de  seguir laborando para que sus negocios crezcan. Es por esta razón que ellas desde los primeros días de este año trabajaran arduamente.
texts.en:
The group “El Aguacate” consists of Silvia L., Eloisa L., and Miriam V.. Silvia started her business selling food out of necessity and because she saw the demand among workers employed by businesses in her neighborhood to purchase something to eat. Her fellow group members, Eloisa and Miriam, sell clothing of different styles.

They wish to start the New Year with the work, strength, and hope needed to continue growing their businesses. This is why they have worked so hard the first few days of this year.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is a 31-year-old university student and a single mother who lives with her two sons in La Suiza de Turrialba, a region in the Central Valley of Costa Rica. She has a business selling various products such as clothing, jewelry and cosmetics by going door-to-door in her community as well as at her university: Universidad de Florencio Castillos.

This will be Jessica’s 3rd loan with Fundacion Mujer. Her 2nd was for 200,000 colons and was paid back on time and in full. She is happy to be applying for a larger amount (500,000 colons) than she has in the past.

Jessica’s clients have been requesting a more diverse range of products such as hand creams and other items she currently does not offer. This loan will be used to satisfy those demands. Specifically, Jessica will use this loan to build up her inventory levels by purchasing larger quantities of products from her suppliers in San Jose. Jessica is confident that a larger volume in purchases will guarantee her a lower price and allow for higher profit margins.

Jessica says that her lack of working capital is her main limitation. Testaments to her acute business sense are her ability to triple her client base since she opened her business in 2007 and her success in implementing and enforcing a policy for her credit clients (people who buy clothes on credit) of no more than 60 days of credit.

Prior to enrollment in university and starting her own business, Jessica worked as a receptionist for two years. She says “I enjoyed my job, but I didn’t see myself there permanently.” She started her business in order to earn a supplemental income with an initial investment of 100,000 colons from her first loan with Fundacion Mujer. With her business, in a good month she can earn 400,000 colons, in a bad month only 200,000.

When she isn’t making sales or taking care of her children, Jessica attends classes in the afternoons and at night. The income she generates from sales is the only source of family income other than 80,000 colons per month she receives from the father of one of her sons.

Jessica’s dream job would be to become either a radiologist or a family lawyer. However, she has decided to study special education, to be able to teach children with mental and physical disabilities. She is in her first term of a four-year program and has decided to become a teacher because it will allow her spend more time with her children.

Jessica’s goals are to provide a better quality of living for her children. It is important to her that she raise her sons to have strong principles.

Jessica is an accomplished, determined and competent entrepreneur shown by her ability to build a house, attend university and take care of her two children. Since opening her business, her client base has grown significantly, a demonstration of her ability to effectively use past loans to strengthen her business. In order to balance her numerous demanding daily responsibilities, Jessica has become adept at time management. When her children are sleeping, Jessica studies or cleans the house; in the afternoons, she makes sales in the community; in the evenings, she attends night classes.

loans.use: To build up her inventory levels by purchasing larger quantities of products

loans.name: Las Bellas Group

texts.es:
Jenny C., Sandra P. y Marlene C. integran al grupo Las Bellas. Ellas son tres féminas luchadoras que poco a poco a pesar de sus dificultades económicas han ido progresando y le han enseñado a sus hijos a salir a adelante y a no rendirse ante la adversidad.

Yenni C. desde muy tempranas horas empieza su dia de lavor con las compra de para luego realizar unos deliciosos platillos que degustaran sus clientes. Mientras su compañera Sandra P. tiene una carnicería y Marlene C. comercializa productos de belleza.
texts.en:
Jenny C., Sandra P. and Marlene C. form the Las Bellas [The Beauties] group. They are three fighting women who, little by little, despite their economic difficulties, have progressed and taught their children to get ahead and not to give up in the face of adversity. Jenny C. works from early in the morning, she goes shopping in order to later cook delicious dishes that her clients will taste. Meanwhile, her companion Sandra P. owns a butcher's shop and Marlene C. sells beauty products.

Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients

loans.name: Jorge Enrique

texts.es:
Jorge P. de 31 años de edad, tiene una casa de ladrillos en la que tiene agua y luz como servicio básico, su casa esta ubicada en Paraíso de Guayaquil, esta casado hace 11 años y tiene 2 niños uno de 6 años y otro de 10 años los dos estudian en una escuela fiscal.

Jorge comenzó trabajando en una granja haciendo chifles una vez que se decidió ir a Guayaquil a vivir puso su puesto de fabricación de chifles ya hace 7 años atrás. Ahora Jorge trabaja en conjunto con su esposa y un ayudante desde las 08h00 hasta las 20h00, Diario vende 400 pacas de chifles en las que cada paca viene 1500 fundas de chifles.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar aceites y verdes para agrandar más el negocio, en el futuro quiere poner su propia marca en las fundas de chifles y tener más empleados que les ayuden.
texts.en:
Jorge P., 31 years old, owns a brick house in which he has water and electricity as basic utilities. His home is located in Paraíso in Guayaquil. He has been married for 11 years and he has two sons, a 6 years old one and a 10 years old one. Both study at a public school.

Jorge began working in a farm, manufacturing plantain chips. Once he decided to move to Guayaquil he set up his plantain chips manufacture stall, 7 years ago. Now Jorge works along side his wife and a helper from 8 am till 8 pm. He sells daily 400 packages of plantain chips, and each package contains 1,500 bags of plantain chips.

With the loan he wants to buy oil and green bananas to increase his business further. In the future he wants to establish his own brand name of plantain chips bags and hire more employees to help him.

Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Oil, green bananas

loans.name: Juan Francisco

texts.es:
Juan A. de 53 años de edad, tiene una casa de cemento que esta ubicada en Paraíso de Guayaquil, esta casado tiene 3 hijos uno de 17 años y los otros ya mayores de edad.

Juan por consejo de uno de sus hijos mayores invirtió en un taller de cerrajería ya que su hijo le enseñaría todo con respecto a cerrajería porque el trabajo en un taller de cerrajería, así poco a poco fue creciendo el negocio en conjunto con su hijo ahora Juan trabaja desde las 09h00 hasta las 17h00 vende de 10 a 15 puertas semanales una de las complicaciones es su salud y la competencia.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar tubos, platillos, planchas para agrandar mas el negocio, en el futuro quiere crear una sucursal de cerrajería para su hijo.
texts.en:
Juan A., 53 years old, owns a concrete house located in Paraíso, Guayaquil. He is married and has three sons, one is 17 years old and the other two are already of legal age.

Following the advice of one of his older sons, Juan invested in an ironworks workshop. His son would teach him everything about ironworks, because he used to work in an ironworks shop himself. This way, the business grew little by little with his son's help. Now Juan works from 9 am to 5 pm and he sells about 10 to 15 doors every week. Some of the difficulties he faces are his health and the competition.

With the loan he wants to purchase tools to increase his business further, and in a future he wants to create an ironworks workshop branch for his son.

Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tools

loans.name: Kelly Silvana

texts.es: La Srta. Kelly es una cliente que trabaja con nosotros en tres secuencias, ella es madre soltera  tiene una hija de 3 años, que atiende su mamá debido a que ella estudia pòr las mañanas. La mamá le colaboró en la adquisición del kiosco para que ella pueda mantenerse y con un pequeño capital ella comenzo a trabajar, al momento ella aumento su capital en más de 6000 mil bolivianos que hace rotar en mercaderia cada quince dias, Kelly tiene una edad de 21 años, y es una persona muy responsable y madura para su edad.
texts.en:
Kelly is a client who has worked with us in three sequences. She is a single mother, and she has a three year old daughter. Kelly’s mother takes care of her daughter because Kelly goes to school in the mornings. Her mother collaborated with her in acquiring a kiosk so that she could support herself. With a small amount of capital she started to work. She increased her capital to over 6,000 bolivianos, which allows her to rotate her merchandise every 15 days. Kelly is 21 years old. She is a very mature and responsible person for her age.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Lucero Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LUCERO” y viven en la ciudad del Cusco del departamento del Cusco. Los socios se reúnen cada 30 días en la oficina central de la Asociación Arariwa y esta conformado por 24 socios. En el video se ve que la asesora hace juramentar a la nueva junta directiva del banco comunal. La nueva presidenta da unas palabras de saludos por las fiestas navideñas y por el año nuevo a los socios.

Nuestros socios tienen pequeños negocios en sus propios domicilios como por ejemplo: Clorinda tiene una carpintería, Luz mariana tiene una panadería, Soledad y Bony cada una tiene una tienda de abarrotes, Carmen tiene un restaurante, Mercedes vende productos secos, Ismael vende auto partes de carros y Francisca vende carne de cordero. 
Otros socios dan servicios como la socia Luz Marina que es profesora del nivel inicial, Justina es empleada del hogar, Delia es secretaria en el colegio I.E.I. “San Jerónimo” y Los socios Vilma y Juan que son esposos y tienen un negocio familiar de servicio de agencia de transportes terrestre que llevan pasajeros a la ciudad de Puerto Maldonado. 

Nuestra socia Bertha tiene 34 años es casada y tiene dos hijos, ella se dedica a lavar ropa de sus amigas y sus vecinas todos los días, de esa forma ayuda al ingreso económico de su familia. La socia es una madre emprendedora y trabajadora que saca adelante a sus hijos. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. La socia require el prestamo para el gasto familiar. 
  
Los socios que tienen negocios requieren el préstamo para comprar productos como madera, harina, arroz, azúcar, auto partes y los que brindan servicios para el gasto familiar como la educación de sus hijos.       

Los socios valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y así mismo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our members belong to the “Lucero” communal bank and they live in the city of Cusco, in the department of Cusco. The group meets every 30 days in the main office of the Asociación Ararwia and it is made up of 24 members. In the video you can see the advisor swearing in the communal bank’s new executive board. The new president says a few words of holiday and New Years greetings to the members. Our members have small businesses in their own homes, such as: Clorinda has a carpentry shop, Luz Mariana has a bakery store, Soledad and Bony each have a small grocery store, Carmen has a restaurant, Mercedes sells dry food products, Ismael sells car parts, and Francisca sells lamb meat. Other members provide services: Luz Marina is a pre-school teacher, Justina is a domestic, Delia is a secretary at the high school I.E.I. “San Jeronimo”, and Vilma and Juan, who are spouses, have a family-owned bus company that takes passengers to the city of Puerto Maldonado. Our member Bertha is 34 years old, she is married and has two children. She washes clothes for her friends and neighbors every day and in this way she helps with an income for her family. She is an entrepreneurial and hardworking mother who helps her children get ahead in life. She has been in this line of work for several years and things have gone well for her because of the effort she puts into her work. She will put her loan towrds her family's living expenses. The members who have the business need the loan to buy products such as wood, flour, rice, sugar, and car parts, while those who provide services need it for family expenses such as their children’s education. The members value and appreciate the loan granted to them through this program and they are committed to making their repayments in the established time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The members who have the business need the loan to buy products such as wood, flour, rice, sugar, and car parts, while those who provide services need it for family expenses such as their children’s education.

loans.name: Ana Alba

texts.es:
Ana P. de 26 años de edad, tiene una casa de caña con luz y agua como servicios básicos su casa esta ubicada en Paraíso de Guayaquil, es madre soltera tiene 1 hijo de 5 años que esta en una escuela particular.

Ana comenzó con unos pequeños ahorros vendiendo papi-pollo en una carreta así poco a poco incremento más  su negocio con mesas y sillas y así pudo alquilar un lugar y poner un puesto de comidas rápidas. Ahora Ana trabaja de lunes a domingos desde las 12h00 hasta el anochecer. Una de las mayores complicaciones es el traslado de la materia prima hasta el local. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, pollos, chuletas para poder agrandar el negocio, en el futuro quiere poner otra sucursal y así poder arreglar su casa con más seguridad.
texts.en:
Ana P. is 26 years old. She has a house made of sugar cane stalks. She has light and water service. Her house is located in Paraíso de Guayaquil. She is a single mother, and she has a five year old son who is in private school. With a small amount of savings Ana started selling “papi-pollo” (a typical dish with chicken and potatoes) from a cart. Little by little she increased her business and added tables and chairs. That way she was able to rent a place and set up a fast food stand. Now Ana works from Monday to Sunday from twelve until nightfall. One of the biggest problems is transporting the raw materials to her location. She will use the loan to buy rice, chicken, and chops to be able to enlarge her business. In the future she wants to set up another branch and be able to fix her house with more security.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rice, chicken, and chops

loans.name: Argelis Rolando

texts.es:
Argelis N. de 27 años, su casa es de cemento y esta ubicada en Paraíso de Guayaquil, su esposa trabaja como profesora parvularia en el Instituto Simon Bolívar  en Guayaquil tiene 2 hijos uno de 1 año y otro de 5 meses.

Argelis comenzó trabajando en la farmacia de su mama poco a poco pudo reunir dinero y comprarle la farmacia, después de unos años para tener otro ingreso adicional puso a lado de la farmacia la tienda con unas pocas cosas, ahora Arcelis trabaja desde las 06h00 hasta las 00h30 de lunes a domingo en la farmacia y la tienda, una de las mayores complicaciones son los racionamientos de electricidad del gobierno. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar dulces, víveres, arroz, para la tienda. En el futuro quiere expandir su negocio con una sucursal e incrementar los productos que vende.
texts.en:
Argelia N. is 27 years old. His house is made of cement, and it is located in Paraíso de Guayaquil. His wife works as a nursery school teacher in the Simon Bolívar Institue in Guayaquil. He has two children; one is one year old and the other is five months. Argelis started working in his mother’s pharmacy. Little by little he was able to get together money to buy the pharmacy. In order to have additional income, a few years later he put a store with a few things next to the pharmacy. Arcelis now works from six until three from Monday to Sunday in the pharmacy and the store. One of the biggest problems is the rationing of electricity by the government. With the loan he wants to buy sweets, supplies, and rice for the store. In the future he wants to expand his business with a branch and increase the products that he sells.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sweets, supplies, and rice

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Sra. Juana es Madre soltera con 6 hijos nació en Chuquisaca desde muy niña empezo a trabajar y  hace 22 años que trabaja y vive en la comunidad el Porvenir a 40 Km De la comunidad el Torno ella cuenta con su propia parcela y sus ganados actualmente esta cosechando maíz y sésamo para despues poder comercializarlo en el mercado de la comunidad.
La cliente trabaja con sus hijos para asi poder ayudar con los gastos del hogar sus hijos de la Sra. juana están agradecidos con al institución por la confianza depositada.
texts.en:
Señora Juana is a single mother with 6 children. She was born in Chuquisaca. She began to work at an early age and for 22 years she has worked and lived in the community el Porvenir located 40 Km from el Torno. She relies on her own plot of land and cattle. At present she is raising corn and sesame to be able to later sell it in the community market. The client works with her children in order to help with the household expenses. The children of Señora Juana are thankful to the institution for the confidence placed in her.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for her farm.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
La sra. Margarita vive en casa propia, tiene una tienda - Ferreteria ubicado en su domicilio , donD. ella demuestra ser trabajadora y responsable. La Sra Margarita es divorsiada, tras la separacion ella salio adelante sola cuenta que fue dificil para ella la separacion y tambien para sus hijos y no le quedo otra que trabajar duro  para asi poder sacar adelante a sus hijos menores. La Sra.
